School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering/Key Laboratory for Green Processing of Chemical Engineering of Xinjiang Bingtuan Shihezi University Shihezi 832000 PR China Graphical abstract Supported Ru-L x /AC catalysts were synthesised by coordinating a Ru precursor with several azole ligands and assessed for acetylene hydrochlorination. The results demonstrated that the coordinated Ru-imidazole/AC (Ru-L1/AC) catalyst exhibited superior catalytic activity compared to that of catalysts coordinated with other ligands. In addition, the substitution of hydrogen on the imidazole ring by electron-donating substituents further improved the catalytic performance. Specifically, the coordination between the ruthenium precursor and heteroatom in the ligands, which contain a conjugated structure and an electron-donating substituent, promoted the transfer of electrons from the heteroatom to Ru cation and augmented the electron cloud density around the active centres, which helps stabilise high-valence Ru and produce more active Run+ species. In addition, the coordination contributed to the anchoring and dispersion of active species, which improved the catalytic hydrochlorination of acetylene. Thus, the as-designed Ru-1-isopropyl imidazole/AC (Ru-L8/AC) catalyst exhibits a superior performance and good application prospect. Keywords Ru-based catalysts Azole ligands Coordination Enhanced performance 1 Introduction Polyvinyl chloride (PVC) is a type of thermoplastic resin, which is synthesised from vinyl chloride monomer (VCM) under the action of an initiator. PVC is the second largest general-purpose resin in the world. It is widely used in industry, agriculture, construction and daily necessities [1–3]. The coal-derived carbide acetylene method is economically advantageous in the coal-rich regions [4–6]. Currently, carbon-supported mercuric chloride is used for acetylene hydrochlorination. However, the sublimation and high toxicity of the general-purpose mercury-based catalyst used in this process decrease its activity and present a hazard to people and the environment [7,8]. According to the report, China consumes approximately 800 tonnes of Hg-based catalyst per year for PVC production, and more than a quarter of HgCl2 cannot be recovered during the reaction [9]. To eliminate mercury consumption in the PVC industry by 2025, as scheduled in the Minamata Convention [10], the exploration of economical mercury-free catalysts is essential for the sustainable development of the chlor-alkali industry. Currently, laboratory-scale studies have shown that precious metal catalysts (e.g. Au, Pd, Pt and Rh) exhibit good catalytic performance [11–17]. For example, Au-based catalysts with secondary metal additives (e.g. Cu [18–20], La [21], Ba [22], Li [23], Cs [24], Bi [25] or Sn [26]) have further extended the stability of catalysts. G.J. Hutchings and co-wokers designed and developed different Au complexes to improve the service life of catalysts. The Au-S complex exhibited good catalytic performance during the reaction, and the presence of S improved the stability of the Au cation. A 0.1 wt% Au/C catalyst, which was prepared with Na3Au(S2O3)2 as a precursor, achieved the production of 1000 kg of VCM with 1 kg of catalyst in an industrial experiment [4]. On the basis of the advantages of low volatility, good solubility, polarity and weak intermolecular interaction, ionic liquids (ILs) are widely used as non-metallic catalysts for acetylene hydrochlorination [6,27]. In addition, ILs are employed to modify metallic catalysts. For instance, X. Li and co-wokers synthesised an Au-IL/AC catalyst by coordinating an ionic liquid ([Prmim]Cl) and chloroauric acid [28] and then designed an Au-Cu-IL/AC catalyst (0.1-wt% Au loading, 0.8-wt% Cu loading and 10-wt% IL loading) [29]. The presence of CuCl2 enables the reduced Au(0) during the reaction process to be in situ oxidised to Au(III) species in the ionic liquid. Then, Au(III) species can be stabilised by the electron transfer from Cu species. It is incontestable that the Au-based catalysts exhibit excellent performance, but they have a considerable one-time investment in industrial application. To our knowledge, the abundance of Au in the crust is 0.0031 ppm, and it is mainly used in jewelry decoration, currency manufacturing and gold bar processing, while only ca. 8.7 % of it is used for other purposes, including catalysts. Although the abundance of Ru, which had also been proved to be an active metal for acetylene hydrochlorination [30,31], is 0.001 ppm in the earth's crust, the price of commercially available RuCl3 is about a fifth to a tenth of the price of HAuCl4·4H2O, and it is mainly used as a catalyst in the petrochemical industry, rather than for monetary and decorative purposes [32]. Therefore, if it can exhibit excellent catalytic performance, it will be possible to improve the economics of the catalysts. Over the past few years, considerable efforts were devoted to further enhance their catalytic performance [30,32]. In our previous studies, Ru/SAC (spherical activated carbon), Ru-Co/SAC, Ru-Cu/SAC and Ru-Co-Cu/SAC catalysts were prepared via wet impregnation. It was determined that Ru catalysts exhibited better catalytic activity for the reaction. The conversion of acetylene by the Ru1Co3/SAC catalyst was higher than 95 %. However, there was a lower content and poor dispersion of the active species in Ru/SAC, and the catalyst was easily deactivated by the coke deposition and the aggregation of active components [33]. Co(III) and Cu(II) species could interact strongly with Ru species and lessen the agglomeration of active species. Synergistically, the Co(III) additives could interact closely with RuCl3 precursors to form more high valent Ru species, whereas Cu(II) species could not only inhibit the reduction of RuCl3 precursors, but also make Co(II) or Co(0) transform to high valent Co(III) species, resulting in more high valent Ru active species and enhanced catalytic activity of the catalyst [34]. Heteroatoms have an unshared pair of electrons and tend to interact strongly with metals, which suggests that heteroatom modification may be a strategy to enhance the performance of catalysts. We studied the effect of modified carrier by nitrogenous groups on the catalytic performance of the catalysts. The modification increased the content of active species in the catalyst and enhanced the adsorption ability for HCl and the desorption ability for VCM, which improved the activity of the catalyst [35]. In our recent work, a carbon-supported Ru-TPPB catalyst (particle size: 1.91 nm) was prepared by interacting RuCl3 with tetraphenyl phosphonium bromide (TPPB) [36]. The weak force of local structural domain increased the dispersion of Ru cluster species from 23.3%–60%, which inhibited the reduction of active species, enhanced the adsorption ability for HCl and the desorption ability for VCM, and weakened the adsorption of C2H2. However, the long-term stability of the catalyst needs to be further improved. In our previous study, imidazolium-based ionic liquids (IBILs) were adopted to prepare Ru-based catalysts for the hydrochlorination of acetylene [37]. It was determined that IBIL additives improved the dispersion of active species and inhibited coke deposition owing to the interactions between the additives and Ru species. In addition, the performance of the optimal Ru10 % [BMIM] BF4/AC catalyst was considerably improved compared with that of the Ru/AC catalyst. Y. Li and co-workers synthesised the N-doped ordered mesoporous carbon catalyst (Ru-N-OMC) in one step using RuCl3/SBA-15, urea and sucrose as a hard template, nitrogen source and carbon source, respectively [38]. Ru particles (particle size: approximately 2.0 nm) were uniformly dispersed and inserted into the carbon matrix. The doped N and Ru particles co-acted as active sites to catalyse the hydrochlorination of acetylene, which enhanced the activity of the catalyst. However, Ru catalysts inevitably encountered deactivation owing to the reduction of metal cations by the reductive C2H2 gas and the coke deposition originating from the oligomerisation of acetylene or VCM during the reaction. In addition, the dispersion of active species and their atomic utilisation rate are still relatively poor. It is known that Ru ions possess similar peripheral s, p and d equivalent orbitals. Thus, it is easier to form hybrid orbitals with strong bonding ability to accept a lone pair of electrons provided by hetero-atomic ligands, and the electrostatic effect on the ligand is generally stronger. The unsaturated d-orbital in the Ru ion induces considerable deformability, which enhances the coordination bond between the central atom and the ligand. As a type of important heterocyclic compounds, azole ligands are rich in N heteroatoms. The heteroatoms have a coordination effect on the metal ion to form a chelate compound with a stable cationic resonant structure and spatial topologies. Therefore, in this work, azole ligands were chosen to complex with a Ru precursor aiming to anchor, stabilise and disperse active Ru species and augment the stability of catalysts. At the same time, the effects of different nitrogen heterocyclic structures on the performance of the catalysts were studied by various characterisation techniques. 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemicals AC (coconut) was provided by S. S. Activated Carbon Co., Ltd. Ruthenium trichloride hydrate was provided by Zhengzhou Alfa Chemical Co., Ltd. Azole ligands were purchased from Tansoole. All the solvents were used as received. 2.2 Catalyst preparation Ru-Lx/AC (1 wt% Ru, x = 1, 2, ..., 9) catalysts were prepared according to previous literature [39], and the procedures are briefly described as follows. 1 g of RuCl3·3H2O was added into 100 mL of deionised water to yield a dilute solution with a concentration of Ru of 0.0039 g mL−1. Then, a certain amount of azole ligand (a molar ratio of Ru/L = 1:1) was dissolved in 8.4 mL of deionised water, and 11.6 mL of the prepared Ru solution was transferred to the abovementioned mixture and stirred for 30 min. Finally, 4.5 g of AC was poured into a round-bottom flask with stirring, refluxed at 60 °C for 20 h, followed by vacuum drying at 80 °C for 12 h. The resultant product was labelled as the Ru-Lx/AC catalyst, where L denotes L1: imidazole, L2: pyrazole, L3: 1,2,4-triazole, L4: tetrazolium, L5: imidazole-1-yl-acetonitrile, L6: 1-methyl-2-hydroxymethyl-1-hydrogen imidazole, L7: imidazole-4-ethyl formate, L8: 1-isopropyl imidazole and L9: 1-allyl imidazole. The ligand structures were also shown in Fig. 1 . For comparison, Ru/AC and L/AC were prepared using the same method as that used for the Ru-Lx/AC catalysts without adding a ligand or Ru solution during the corresponding preparation process. 2.3 Catalyst evaluation The prepared catalysts were assessed in a self-made fixed-bed micro-reactor (length: 650 mm, outer diameter: 24 mm, internal diameter: 8 mm) at 0.1 MPa and 180 °C. Prior to the initiation, the entire system was purified with nitrogen gas (20 mL min−1) for 30 min to remove foreign gases. Then, 2.4 g of the catalyst was added and activated with an HCl gas with a flow of 17.25 mL min−1. When the temperature controlled by a Yudian AI thermostat was slowly increased to the reaction temperature (180 °C), purified C2H2 (15 mL min−1) gas was forced into the reactor to initiate the reaction. The gaseous products were first bubbled into the lye to remove the unreacted HCl gas and then analysed with a Shimadzu gas chromatograph (GC2014C) to quantitatively assess the performance of the catalyst. The schematic of the microreactor for acetylene hydrochlorination was shown in Fig. 2 . 2.4 Catalyst characterisation The absolute content of ruthenium in fresh and used catalysts was determined by a Varian 725-ES inductively coupled plasma-atomic emission spectrometry (ICP-AES). Prior to the test, a small portion of the catalyst was digested in aqua regia. A MADAPA UV-6100 s double beam spectrophotometer was used for the UV–vis spectroscopic analysis of liquid samples with suitable concentrations, and the wavelength range was 200–800 nm. Texture parameters were obtained by conducting a low-temperature N2 adsorption-desorption experiment with a Micromeritics ASAP 2020C instrument. The sample was first degassed at 150 °C for 6 h, followed by the adsorption and desorption in liquid nitrogen. The data were recorded for the P/Po range of 0.01–1.0. The carbon deposition of the catalyst was evaluated by conducting a thermogravimetric (TG) analysis on a MTTLER TOLEDO TGA2 thermal analyser. The data were recorded when the temperature was increased from 25 °C to 800 °C at a rate of 10 °C min−1 under a 30 mL min−1 air flow. The dispersion of active species was indirectly assessed by conducting an X-ray diffraction (XRD) experiment on a Bruker D8 instrument. The pattern data of each catalyst was collected in the range of 10–90° (2θ) at the operation conditions of 40 mA and 40 kV. Then, the dispersion was directly observed using transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images on a FEI Tecnai G2 F30 S-Twin electron microscope operated at 200 kV. The grounded catalyst was evenly dispersed in anhydrous ethanol and dropped on a copper grid. The relative content and valence state of Ru species in each catalyst were evaluated by conducting temperature programmed reduction (TPR) experiments with a Quantachrome Chembet Pulsar TPR/temperature programmed desorption (TPD) instrument. First, each sample (0.1 g) was purged with helium (a flow of 30 mL min−1) at 100 °C for 1 h to remove foreign gases. After cooling, the TCD signal was collected under a 10 % H2/Ar atmosphere (30 mL min−1) when the sample was heated from 40 °C to 900 °C (10 °C min−1). The valence and relative content of Ru species on the surface of the catalysts were detected by conducting X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis with a PHI Versa Probe instrument. The Ru3p spectral profiles were recorded with an overlap of Ru3d signal with N1s, and the spectra were calibrated by the C1s peak at 284.6 eV. The adsorption ability of the reactants was assessed by carrying out TPD experiments with a Quantachrome Chembet Pulsar TPR/TPD instrument. First, the sample (0.1 g) was treated in C2H2 or HCl (a flow of 20 mL min−1) at 180 °C for 5 h to fully adsorb the corresponding reactants. After cooling, the treated catalyst was purged with helium (a flow of 30 mL min−1) at 100 °C for 1 h to remove weakly absorbed gases. Then, a TCD signal was collected when the catalyst was heated from 40 °C to 800 °C (at 10 °C min−1) under helium atmosphere (a flow of 30 mL min−1). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic performance of Ru-based catalysts Fig. 3 shows the catalytic activity and the selectivity of the Ru-Lx/AC catalysts for acetylene hydrochlorination. Under the reaction conditions, AC shows a relatively low activity, with a stable acetylene conversion of ca. 7 %. The activity of the Ru/AC catalyst begins to decline from the beginning of the reaction. Specifically, the acetylene conversion decreases from 71 % to 58 % during the 24 h assessment (Fig. 3a). The introduction of ligands, except for L4, considerably enhances the catalytic activity and stability of Ru catalysts. The acetylene conversions of 96.5 %, 83.1 %, 85.8 % and 52.5 % can be achieved using the Ru-L1/AC, Ru-L2/AC, Ru-L3/AC and Ru-L4/AC catalysts, respectively. Moreover, when L1 (imidazole) is adopted, Ru-L1/AC maintains high and stable catalytic activity without any decrease during the reaction process. Therefore, the effects of the structure of imidazole ligands on the catalytic performance of the catalysts were also studied. The substitution of ethyl formate on the imidazole ligand has a negligible effect on the catalytic performance of the catalyst. However, the introduction of substituents at other sites enhances the activity of the corresponding catalysts (Fig. 3b). When the 1-isopropyl imidazole (L8) ligand is coordinated with the Ru precursor, the acetylene conversion reaches approximately 100 % under the action of the Ru-L8/AC catalyst. Moreover, the Ru-L8/AC catalyst can still exhibit relatively good catalytic performance even at a higher GHSV(C2H2) of 720 h−1 adopted to differentiate the activity of catalysts (Fig. S1). At the same time, the selectivity of the catalyst is slightly increased with the introduction of the ligand. Specifically, the selectivity to VCM is higher than 97 % (Fig. 3c). It can be inferred that the structure of azole ligands may affect the electronic properties of the active components of the catalysts, which needs to be verified by the further characterisation analysis. 3.2 Interaction between Ru species and azole ligands Fig. 4 shows the UV–vis diffuse reflection spectra of the solution of ligand (for example, L8), Ru and Ru-ligand. It is observed that there is a clear absorption peak at 287 nm in the spectrum of the ligand. In the spectrum of the Ru solution, two absorption peaks are observed at ca. 326 nm and 433 nm, which correspond to the d-d transition of Run+. The spectra of the Ru-ligand solution before impregnation are approximately the same as those of the Ru solution, with a relative intensity shifting towards the higher values. Moreover, compared with the Ru solution, the central Ru-L wavelength of the two characteristic absorption peaks (310 nm and 420 nm) of the solution shift towards the absorption peak of pure ligand. This observation indicates that there may be a chelation between the ligand and Ru species, and the electron cloud derived from N in the ligands moves towards Run+, which helps form Ru complexes [40]. The XPS technique can be adopted as an effective tool to further confirm the coordination of the complexes. Fig. S2 and Table 1 show that the Ru 3p spectrum of a conventional Ru/AC catalyst can be characterised by four types of species, such as Ru0, Ru3+, Ru4+ and Run+ (n > 4) at ca. 461.9 eV, 463.4 eV, 465.1 eV and 467.8 eV [30,33,34,41,42]. It is not difficult to determine that compared to the Ru/AC catalyst, ruthenium species mainly exist as high-valent Run+ species in the unused Ru-Lx/AC, and the binding energies of Run+ are significantly shifted. Moreover, compared to the binding energies of N heteroatoms in the Lx/AC catalyst, those in the Ru-Lx/AC catalysts shift towards higher binding energies (Fig. S3). These results indicate the successful coordination of the ruthenium precursor and ligands. 3.3 Structural properties of the prepared Ru catalysts Table 2 shows the structural parameters of the prepared catalysts. The pore structure of activated carbon is well-developed with an appreciable specific surface area (SBET) of 1067 m2 g−1 and a total pore volume (VP) of 0.56 cm3 g−1. The loading of Ru decreases SBET and VP because of the partial occupation of porous channels by the tiny ruthenium particles [32]. In addition, the comparison of Smicro/SBET, Sext/SBET and Dpore indicates that the pore structure of the support is dominated by micropores, and the introduction of ligands does not considerably change the average pore diameter, which can be verified by the H4 hysteresis loop of all catalysts (Fig. S4). After the reaction, the decreased SBET, VP and Smicro/SBET and increased Sext/SBET and Dpore suggest the blockage of the micropores, which may originate from the deposition of byproducts [32]. The introduction of ligands suppressed the extent of the decreased SBET (△S BET%) and VP (△V P%) in the decreasing order of AC > Ru/AC > Ru-L1/AC > Ru-L8/AC. This result is observed because the introduction of ligands improves the activity of Ru-based catalysts, promotes the addition reaction between acetylene and hydrogen chloride, and thus reduces the deposition of polymerised byproducts. This can be verified by the thermogravimetric analysis, which is an effective method to detect carbon deposition during the reaction [43]. As shown in Fig. 5 , a clear weight loss is observed for the fresh Ru-L8/AC catalyst when the sample is heated from 25 °C to 100 °C. This loss is attributed to the vaporisation of moisture and the desorption of weakly-adsorbed foreign gases. The changes without weight loss, which are observed in the DTG curves of both the unused and used catalysts when the heating temperature increases from 100 °C to 417 °C, indicate the weight loss of coke rather than the decomposition of the ligand (Fig. S5). The rapid weight loss in both samples when the test temperature is greater than 417 °C is clearly attributed to the combustion of carbon support. Therefore, the difference in the weight change of the used and fresh catalysts can be calculated to reflect the amount of coke deposition [37,44]. Therefore, the carbon deposition on other catalysts during the reaction is also analysed, as shown in Fig. S6 and Table 3 . The Ru/AC catalyst does produce a relatively heavy carbon deposition during the reaction, and the introduction of ligands effectively inhibits the production of carbon deposition. This observation is consistent with the analysis of the texture parameter trends of various catalysts and is also closely related to the different structures and catalytic activities of the active species formed by the coordination of different ligands with the Ru precursor. 3.4 Dispersion and the crystalline phase of the active species The coordination of N-containing ligands with the Ru precursor aims to anchor and disperse the active Ru species, and XRD patterns and TEM images were obtained to support this assumption. Fig. 6 shows that all unused and spent catalysts, including the AC, Ru/AC and Ru-Lx/AC catalysts, exhibit three amorphous diffraction peaks of AC at 24.5°, 43.3° and 79.5° (2θ), and no distinguishable ruthenium crystal diffraction peaks can be detected. This indicates that the active Ru species are highly dispersed or exist on the carrier surface in an amorphous form, and they do not agglomerate during the reaction [45]. The TEM images of unused catalysts show that the active Ru particles are evenly dispersed on the carrier surface, which is consistent with the XRD results (Table S1). However, compared to the unused Ru/AC catalyst, the introduction of ligands further improves the dispersion of the active components, with the decreased average particle diameter from 2.53 nm (Fig. S7a) to almost atomic level. The active components of the catalysts are difficult to distinguish in TEM images (Figs. 7 c and 7e). However, the presence of isolated active atoms can be observed in high-angle annular dark-field scanning TEM (HAADF-STEM) images (Fig. S8), which is related to the high steric hindrance of the ligands. A slight sintering occurs in the catalysts during the reaction. Specifically, sintering is clearly observed in the Ru/AC catalyst because the average particle diameter of the ruthenium particles increases from 2.53 nm (Fig. S7a) to 3.38 nm (Fig. S7b). The introduction of ligands effectively lessened the agglomeration, and the average size of the ruthenium particles in the spent Ru-L8/AC catalysts (Fig. S7d) is much smaller than that in the spent Ru/AC (Fig. S7b) catalyst. These results indicate the dispersing and anchoring effects of nitrogen-containing ligands on the active ruthenium components. The Ru loading in all catalysts was also detected, as shown in Table 4 . The ruthenium loading in fresh catalysts is similar to 1.0 wt%, which is consistent with the theoretical loading described in the experimental section. After 24 h of reaction under the abovementioned conditions, the active components of the Ru/AC catalyst disappear to a certain extent (6.67 %). However, the loss of ruthenium in the Ru-Lx/AC catalysts is considerably reduced owing to the presence of ligands (Table 4), which also proves the anchoring effect of heteroatoms in the ligands on the active components. 3.5 Interaction between the carrier and active species TPR profiles were obtained to elucidate the effect of the ligand on the valence state of the active Ru species and the interaction between the carrier and Ru species. As observed in a previous study [34], in addition to the broad peaks attributed to the reduction of O-containing groups on the surface of the carrier, which appeared at the temperature range of 400–800 °C, three characteristic reduction peaks emerged at 110 °C, 166 °C and 238 °C, in the unused Ru/AC catalyst (Fig. 8 ), which correspond to the reduction of the RuOx, RuO2 and RuCl3 species, respectively [34]. The introduction of ligands increased the reduction temperature of these species in the decreasing order of Ru-L8/AC > Ru-L1/AC > Ru/AC. The increase in the reduction temperature indicates the enhanced interaction between the active species and carrier, which may be caused by the bonding of the other functional groups on the imidazole ring with the functional groups on the surface of the carrier. This can be confirmed by the reduced loss of Ru species determined by the ICP analysis of the fresh Ru-Lx/AC catalysts (Table 4). In addition, sharp peaks suggest that the dispersion of the active components on the carrier surface was considerably improved compared to that on the conventional Ru/AC catalyst, which is consistent with the TEM analysis. Furthermore, the introduction of ligands considerably increases the absolute content of the high-valence state ruthenium species, which is qualitatively determined by calculating the corresponding peak areas of the catalysts at similar Ru loadings in the decreasing order of Ru-L8/AC > Ru-L1/AC > Ru/AC. This observation is consistent with the trend of increasing reduction temperature of the active components in the catalysts. Therefore, the use of imidazole as the ligand enables the catalyst to have more high-valence Ru species, which are suitable active species for acetylene hydrochlorination [38]. Moreover, because the selected imidazole ligand was adopted as the matrix, the electron-donating substituent groups enhance the interaction between the Ru precursor, ligand and carrier, augmenting the reduction temperature and the absolute content of the active component in the catalysts, which is beneficial to the improvement of the catalysts. XPS technique was used to further investigate the valence of the active species on the surface of the unused and used catalysts. Fig. S2 and Table 1 show that when the ligands are introduced, the Ru0 species in the Ru/AC catalyst evolve into high-valence state Run+ species, including the emerging Rum+ (1 < m < 3) species. The substitution of functional groups on the imidazole ring slightly changes the relative content of the high-valence Ru species, which is in good agreement with the TPR analysis. This may be the primary reason why the Ru-L8/AC catalysts exhibit better catalytic activity than the that of the other Ru-based catalysts. Furthermore, when the Ru/AC catalyst undergoes a 24-h reaction, the signal-to-noise ratio decreased significantly, which may be related to the considerable carbon deposition on the surface of the catalyst. In addition, the relative content of the highly oxidised Ru4+ species significantly decreases from 36.0%–22.8%, which suggests that the Ru species were reduced by the reductive gas acetylene, which results in the continuous decline in activity during the reaction. However, the presence of N-containing ligands transfers electrons from N heteroatoms to Run+, thus augmenting the electron cloud density around the active centres, stabilises the high-valence Ru species, and guarantee the sustainable high performance of the catalysts [45]. Moreover, active species still exist in the form of high-valence Run+ (n ≥ 3) in the used Ru-L8/AC catalyst, which indicates the further stabilisation of the high-valence Ru species by the electron-donating substituent groups in the catalysts and leads to the stable superior activity of the Ru-L8/AC catalysts compared to that of the Ru/AC catalyst during the reaction. 3.6 Adsorption ability of the prepared catalysts for the reactants The introduction of ligands affects the electronic properties of the active metals and the adsorption ability of the unused catalysts for the reactants. Additional research will reveal the possible mechanism of this process through dynamic analysis. In the HCl-TPD curves, the peak associated with the desorption of HCl in AC is located in the temperature range of 150–500 °C (Fig. 9 a). The loading of Ru induces the multistatus-adsorbed HCl at the temperature of 280–448 °C. Compared to the traditional Ru/AC catalyst, Ru-L1/AC exhibits a similar profile. However, the adsorption capacities, which were qualitatively analysed by the area of the desorption peaks, differ from each other in the increasing order of AC < Ru/AC < Ru-L1/AC. Therefore, the coordination of the Ru precursor and ligand may promote the electron transfer from the heteroatom to Run+ species, which results in the increased electron cloud density around the active centres and enhances the adsorption of HCl [45]. Interestingly, the substitution of hydrogen in the imidazole ring by the electron-donating group limits the catalyst to the broad singlet state adsorption of hydrogen chloride (Fig. 9a), which indicates the further interaction between the support and formed Ru-Lx active sites. The C2H2-TPD profiles show that, except for AC, the Ru/AC and Ru-Lx/AC catalysts exhibit a clear multistate adsorption of acetylene in the temperature range of 180–700 °C (Fig. 9b). The incorporation of the ligand elevates the desorption temperature in the order of Ru-L8/AC > Ru-L1/AC > Ru/AC > AC (Fig. 9b). In terms of the peak area, the interaction between the imidazole ligand and Ru precursor changes the unused catalyst’s adsorption capacity. Furthermore, the presence of the substituent group has a negligible effect on the desorption temperature of acetylene from the catalysts but it clearly enhances the adsorption amount of acetylene (Fig. 9b). This observation is in agreement with the order of activity of the catalysts and the reported literatures [11,46–48]. It is known that the increase in the electron cloud density of the central metal enhances the adsorption of hydrogen chloride but not conducive to the adsorption of acetylene. Therefore, the adsorption sites of acetylene and hydrogen chloride in the catalyst may be different. The delocalisation and transfer of electrons in the structure of the formed Ru-Lx and the interaction between Ru-Lx and carbon support may improve the ability of the catalyst to adsorb and activate acetylene. However, the reaction mechanism of these catalysts needs to be clearly studied in the future works. In addition, the rate-determining step involves the addition of HCl to the surface metal acetylene complex [11,49]. Moreover, by comparing the peak intensities of the HCl and C2H2 desorption, it is observed that once the Ru-based catalyst is exposed to the feed gases, C2H2 is more easily adsorbed on Ru-Lx/AC than HCl (Fig. 9). Under such conditions, the reaction may follow the typical ER mechanism for the Ru complex catalysts. Specifically, HCl reacts with adsorbed C2H2 on the catalysts to produce VCM. Therefore, the enhanced adsorption and activation ability of the acetylene and hydrogen chloride reactants owing to the introduction of ligands enhances the catalytic hydrochlorination of acetylene by the catalysts. 3.7 DFT calculations In order to further uncover the effect of ligands on the electronic property and adsorption ability of active species, DFT calculations were performed with Gaussian 16 package. Geometries were optimized by using B3LYP with a basis set of 6-31G* for non-metal atoms and SDD for Ru. Atomic dipole corrected Hirshfeld atomic charge (ADCH) and Hirshfeld charge were used to analyze the electron-donating capacity of the azole ligands. All charge distributions were calculated by Hirshfeld. In order to reveal the interaction of the raw reactant (HCl or C2H2) with Ru-Lx, the adsorption energy (Ead) was calculated as follows: Ead = ERu-Lx-reactant - (ERu-Lx + E reactant) Where ERu-Lx-reactant, ERu-Lx and E reactant are the adsorption energy of the Ru-Lx with the raw reactant, the Ru-Lx and the raw C2H2 or HCl reactant, respectively. The adsorption energy for HCl and C2H2 on Ru-Lx are -0.007 ∼ -0.019 eV and -0.017 ∼ -0.027 eV (Table 5 ), respectively, which indicates that C2H2 is preferentially adsorbed and activated by Ru-Lx active sites, and it is in line with the TPD results. In addition, the complexation of Ru precursors with ligands reduces the adsorption energy of the reactants by the active species, thus enhancing the adsorption and activation ability of the active species to the reactants. Moreover, by comparing the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) and the highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) of L8 and RuCl3 (Fig. 10 and Table 6 ), it can be seen that electrons are more easily deviated from the HOMO of L8 to the LUMO of RuCl3. Meanwhile, Mulliken charge is used to analyze the electron-donating capacity of the azole ligands after coordinating with Ru precursor (Table 7 ). It is indicated that the electron-donating quantity decreases in the order of L1 > L2 > L3 > L4, and the introduction of alkyl functional groups (L8) further enhances the electron-donating capacity. This stabilises the Ru species in a high-valence state, and makes it harder to reduce the Ru species and increases the adsorption and activation ability of catalysts for the reactants, which is in line with the TPR, XPS and TPD analysis. 3.8 Long-term stability of the optimal catalyst To determine the potential industrial application prospects, the long-term stability of the optimal catalyst was tested on the basis of the advantages of the introduced ligand. For comparison, it was observed that the activity of the conventional Ru/AC decreased after the reaction began, and the conversion of acetylene decreased from 70.70 % to 33.04 % after 150 h of reaction (Fig. 11 ). However, the Ru-L8/AC catalyst shows a superior stability compared to that of Ru/AC. Specifically, the initial acetylene conversion reached approximately 100 %, and only an 8.55 % decrease in acetylene conversion was observed after 150 h of reaction. In addition, after the ligand was introduced, the selectivity to VCM over the Ru-L8/AC catalyst (99.52 %) was slightly improved compared to that of Ru/AC (98.96 %). Therefore, the results indicate that the as-designed Ru-L8/AC catalyst exhibits superior performance and has a good application prospect for acetylene hydrochlorination. 4 Conclusions A series of azole ligands was selected to prepare the carbon-supported Ru-Lx/AC catalysts and assessed for acetylene hydrochlorination. The results of the activity test showed that among the azole ligands, the coordinated Ru-imidazole/AC (Ru-L1/AC) catalyst exhibited superior catalytic activity, and the substitution of hydrogen on the imidazole ligand by electron-donating substituents further improved the catalytic performance. Specifically, an increase of 72.4 % was achieved for Ru-1-isopropyl imidazole/AC (Ru-L8/AC) under the same reaction conditions as those used for the conventional Ru/AC catalyst. The UV–vis, XPS, BET, TGA, ICP-AES, XRD, TEM and H2-TPR techniques combining with DFT calculation showed that the coordination between Ru and heteroatom in the ligand, especially for the ligands containing a conjugate structure and electron-donating substituents, promoted electron transfer from the heteroatom to Run+ and augmented the electron cloud density around the active centres. This stabilised the Ru species in a high-valence state and made it harder to reduce the Ru species, which increased the relative content of the active Run+ species. Furthermore, the coordination guaranteed the anchoring and high dispersion of active species on the surface of the support. The TPD results showed that the hydrochlorination reaction may follow the typical E–R mechanism for the Ru complex catalysts. The long-term test indicated that the Ru-L8/AC catalyst exhibited a superior stability compared to that of Ru/AC. Specifically, the initial acetylene conversion reached approximately 100 %, and only an 8.55 % decrease in acetylene conversion was observed after 150 h of reaction. These results show a good industrial application prospect of this catalyst owing to its advantages of low cost, ease of preparation and environmental friendliness. coredata.dc:description: Supported Ru-L x /AC catalysts were synthesised by coordinating a Ru precursor with several azole ligands and assessed for acetylene hydrochlorination. The results demonstrated that the coordinated Ru-imidazole/AC (Ru-L1/AC) catalyst exhibited superior catalytic activity compared to that of catalysts coordinated with other ligands. In addition, the substitution of hydrogen on the imidazole ring by electron-donating substituents further improved the catalytic performance. Specifically, the coordination between the ruthenium precursor and heteroatom in the ligands, which contain a conjugated structure and an electron-donating substituent, promoted the transfer of electrons from the heteroatom to Ru cation and augmented the electron cloud density around the active centres, which helps stabilise high-valence Ru and produce more active Run+ species. In addition, the coordination contributed to the anchoring and dispersion of active species, which improved the catalytic hydrochlorination of acetylene. Thus, the as-designed Ru-1-isopropyl imidazole/AC (Ru-L8/AC) catalyst exhibits a superior performance and good application prospect.
coredata.dc:title: Enhanced catalytic performance of activated carbon-supported ru-based catalysts for acetylene hydrochlorination by azole ligands
